_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Miscellaneous Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY: 



1. The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source.



Cymer is a custom chemical manufacturing facility; we handle dimethyamine in the production of some of our products. The same properties of dimethyamine makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling dimethyamine to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle dimethyamine combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of the storage facility combined with the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel. The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.



2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled. 



The primary activity associated with dimethyamine is the manufacture of "urea" base curing agents.  Dimethyamine is used in the production of curing agents and several other compounds for a variety of applications. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. The regulated substance handled at this facility is dimethyamine. The maximum amount of dimethyamine that can be stored at this plant is 40,000 pounds.



3. The worst-case release scenario is the rupture and release of the total maximum contents of the storage vessel limited to 40,000 pounds by administrative controls.



Chemical: Dimethylamine [Methanamine, N-methyl-]

Model Used: OCA guidance reference tables and RMP*Comp

CAS number:  124-40-3 Threat type: Flammable Gas

Scenario type: Worst-case

Quantity released:  40000 pounds

Release type:  Vapor Cloud Explosion

 Estimated di

stance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.3 miles (0.4 kilometers)

Population within distance to endpoint: 14

Public receptors within the distance to endpoint: None

Environmental receptors within the distance to endpoint: None 

Passive mitigation measures considered: None



The alternative release scenarios involve leaks from valve, gasket or hose failures which would go undetected between inspections. The worst case in alternative release scenarios is shown herein:

Chemical: Dimethylamine [Methanamine, N-methyl-]

CAS number: 124-40-3

Threat type: Flammable Gas

Scenario type: Alternative

Release duration: 1200 minutes

Release type: Vapor Cloud Explosion

Release rate: .052 pounds per min

Mitigation measures: NONE

 Estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.02 miles (0.03 kilometers)

 Population within distance to endpoint: 0

Public receptors within the distance to endpoint: None

Environmental receptors within the distance to endpoint: None 

Passive mitigation measures considered: None

The undetected release would result in explosion limited damage. Area of distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.02 miles does not involve occupied building and is within the property of Cymer, LLC.



4. The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.



Training and Pre-Task Briefings for all operational personnel and engineering staff is conducted before all operations of the dimethylamine transfer and storage system (process). Step-by-step operational and emergency procedures are provided and reviewed. Coordination with the LEPC and EMS is made before each loading operation and notification of transfer operations. Cymer is in compliance with the OSHA PSM rule and the EPA RMP rule. The storage system and fire protection system are designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA-58. Cymer operates 24/7, 365 days a year and provides for general oversight of the dimethylamine transfer and storage system as well as twice daily inspections of

system.  Cymer works closely with the Responsible Care Program arm of our supplier for industry best practices in the handling and storage of dimethylamine.

 

5. The five-year accident history. 

Cymer has had no EPA release accidents in the past 5 years.



6. The emergency response program



Environmental, Safety and Health has an emergency response plan, ESH-011 Cymer, LLC Integrated Contingency Plan. This emergency response plan has been coordinated with the Meigs County Emergency Manager and the LEPC. Cymer hazmat team (HAZWOPER) has conducted joint training and drills with the Meigs County fire department and Meigs County EMS.



7. Planned changes to improve safety.



The Dimethylamine (DMA) Storage and Transfer System process has performed without incident since installation. The procedures reviews will be continued to be conducted prior to every operation with a lessons learned review after each operation of the system.
